title: Backup a POS database
text: When setting up a new POS, or replacing a POS, we need to have the database copied from our database PC, or the POS we are replacing. This is done by making a new backup file, and then transfering it to the new POS. This guide will show you how to do a backup. There will be a separate guide for Restoring database(Guide will be linked here), this is when you import the backup we are doing in this guide, onto the new POS. Remeber that you should NOT be using the DDD POS software while backup is being made. There are 3 main things that needs to be copied over from the old POS to the new POS. For now they will be saved on a flash drive(They can also be transfered directly via teamviewer, however this can take hours) Before creating the backups, make a folder to keep them in. Name the folder something like this: "Backups_storename_date" 1.Configuration.txt The first and simplest step, the Configuration.txt file. It is found as shown in the picture below. It simply needs to be copied from the old POS, then dragged and dropped to the new POS in the same location, replacing the already existing Configuration.txt For now, copy the Configuration.txt onto a folder/flashdrive The next two steps are done in the "SQL server management studio". The version of the app depends on the age of the POS. But the steps are the same. Open up the app and press connect I recommend bringing an external flash drive to save the two files we are going to extract. Transfering them via teamviewer can take hours. 2. POS Go to the location shown in the picture below, this is where we will do the rest of our work. Right click on POS and select "tasks" and then "backup" You will be taken to the the popup window shown below. Press remove to get rid of the already existing backup file, and then press Add to make a fresh backup file. You now need to specify a location and a name for the POS backup. The location can be anywhere, i recommend a flash drive. The name should refer to the file type and date. An example would be POSbackup19_02_24.bak It is IMPORTANT that you write the file type extension at the end of the file name yourself. Whatever you chose to name the file, just ad .bak at the end, as shown above. If this is not done, the backup file is not gonna be valid, cannot be imported, and you will have to start over. Press OK, and then OK again in the window shown below It will then extract the backup and you should get the message shown below a few minutes later. Your backup is now done, press ok. 3. POSCONFIG This step is pretty much doing the exact same as shown above in 2. POS, you simply need to do this in another folder (POSCONFIG) as shown below. Press Back up, and do the exact same steps as in the guide for 2. POS. Remember to name this file something different. Like POSCONFIGbackup_storename_date.bak You now have your Backups ready
description:
When setting up a new POS, or replacing a POS, we need to have the database copied from our database PC, or the POS we are replacing. This is done by making a new backup file, and then transfering it to the new POS.  This guide will show you how to do a backup.


There will be a separate guide for Restoring database(Guide will be linked here), this is when you import the backup we are doing in this guide, onto the new POS.



Remeber that you should NOT be using the  DDD POS software while backup is being made.


There are 3 main things that needs to be copied over from the old POS to the new POS. For now they will be saved on a flash drive(They can also be transfered directly via teamviewer, however this can take hours)


Before creating the backups, make a folder to keep them in. Name the folder something like this: 


"Backups_storename_date"





1.Configuration.txt



The first and simplest step, the Configuration.txt file. It is found as shown in the picture below.  It simply needs to be copied from the old POS, then dragged and dropped to the new POS in the same location, replacing the already existing Configuration.txt


For now, copy the Configuration.txt onto a folder/flashdrive







The next two steps are done in the "SQL server management studio". The version of the app depends on the age of the POS. But the steps are the same. Open up the app and press connect 

I recommend bringing an external flash drive to save the two files we are going to extract.  Transfering them via teamviewer can take hours.






2. POS


Go to the location shown in the picture below, this is where we will do the rest of our work.

Right click on POS and select "tasks" and then "backup"



You will be taken to the the popup window shown below. Press remove to get rid of the already existing backup file, and then press Add to make a fresh backup file.


You now need to specify a location and a name for the POS backup. The location can be anywhere, i recommend a flash drive. 


The name should refer to the file type and date. An example would be POSbackup19_02_24.bak 

It is IMPORTANT that you write the file type extension at the end of the file name yourself. Whatever you chose to name the file, just ad .bak at the end, as shown above. If this is not done, the backup file is not gonna be valid, cannot be imported, and you will have to start over. 



Press OK, and then OK again in the window shown below 


It will then extract the backup and you should get the message shown below a few minutes later. 



Your backup is now done, press ok. 

 



3. POSCONFIG


This step is pretty much doing the exact same as shown above in 2. POS, you simply need to do this in another folder (POSCONFIG) as shown below. 



Press Back up, and do the exact same steps as in the guide for 2. POS. Remember to name this file something different. Like POSCONFIGbackup_storename_date.bak


You now have your Backups ready

title: Restore a POS database
text: when setting up a POS, you need to restore the database and configuration in order to have the proper POS settings up and running. Before you can restore a database, you will need a backup. If you are overwriting the database on a POS that has already been used for sales, you might want to do a backup beforehand. Have it on a folder somewhere on the POS PC, just in case you need to revert back to the previous settings. This is useful if for some reason the new configuration is not working, and the POS needs to be up and running before store opening hours etc. When you are restoring a database, make sure the DDD POS software is not running, otherwise this will not work. There are 3 things that needs to be restored. You should at this point already have them saved in a folder/on a flashdrive. 1. Configuration.txt Go to the folder shown below, replace the Configuration.txt file with the one you have containing the new POS configuration. Remember this file name cannot be changed. for good measure, save the old Configuration.txt somewhere in a folder 2. POS Open up SQL Server Management Studio, press connect in the popup window as shown below. Open the Databases folder as shown below, right click on POS, then go to Tasks > Restore > Database In this window, we need to select the backup we wish to restore the database with. Choose "From device", and press the three dots to look for the backup. Press Add Then find your backup in the folder you have saved it to. If you followed the backup guide, it would be on a flash drive, which is very easy to find, as it would be on another drive, scroll to the bottom of the window below to find it. Note that you can have difficulties finding your backup if its located in the desktop folder, it is recommended storing it elsewhere. When the file is selected, press OK. You will come back to window shown below. Now that your backup has been selected, we need to change an option. Press "Options" In options, it is IMPORTANT that we choose the restore option (WITH REPLACE). Check the box and go back to general Back in the general tab, press OK and the database will restore itself with your chosen backup. If everything is done correctly you should be prompted that the database has been restored successfully. You can now move on to the next step 3. POSCONFIG The method for restoring the POSCONFIG is exactly the same as the POS. Go to the POSCONFIG folder as shown below, and from there do the same steps as you did with POS. 4. Restoreconfig The final step is to open up the DDD POS software and type in "restoreconfig" then hit enter. The DDD POS software will restart and get the configuration settings that we have restored in the steps above.
description:
when setting up a POS, you need to restore the database and configuration in order to have the proper POS settings up and running. Before you can restore a database, you will need a backup.


If you are overwriting the database on a POS that has already been used for sales, you might want to do a backup beforehand. Have it on a folder somewhere on the POS PC, just in case you need to revert back to the previous settings. This is useful if for some reason the new configuration is not working, and the POS needs to be up and running before store opening hours etc.



When you are restoring a database, make sure the DDD POS software is not running, otherwise this will not work. 



There are 3 things that needs to be restored. You should at this point already have them saved in a folder/on a flashdrive.


1. Configuration.txt


Go to the folder shown below, replace the Configuration.txt file with the one you have containing the new POS configuration. Remember this file name cannot be changed.


for good measure, save the old Configuration.txt somewhere in a folder





2. POS


Open up SQL Server Management Studio, press connect in the popup window as shown below.


Open the Databases folder as shown below, right click on POS, then go to  Tasks > Restore > Database



In this window, we need to select the backup we wish to restore the database with. Choose "From device", and press the three dots to look for the backup.



Press Add


Then find your backup in the folder you have saved it to. If you followed the backup guide, it would be on a flash drive, which is very easy to find, as it would be on another drive, scroll to the bottom of the window below to find it. 


Note that you can have difficulties finding your backup if its located in the desktop folder, it is recommended storing it elsewhere.


When the file is selected, press OK.


You will come back to window shown below. Now that your backup has been selected, we need to change an option. Press "Options"


In options, it is IMPORTANT that we choose the restore option (WITH REPLACE). Check the box and go back to general


Back in the general tab, press OK and the database will restore itself with your chosen backup.


If everything is done correctly you should be prompted that the database has been restored successfully. You can now move on to the next step


3. POSCONFIG


The method for restoring the POSCONFIG is exactly the same as the POS. Go to the POSCONFIG folder as shown below, and from there do the same steps as you did with POS.



4. Restoreconfig


The final step is to open up the DDD POS software and type in "restoreconfig" then hit enter. The DDD POS software will restart and get the configuration settings that we have restored in the steps above.
